Tsendsuren Munkhdalai

I am a researcher at Microsoft Research Montreal. I spent two years at the University of Massachusetts as a postdoc sitting right next to the neurology department. I got my MSc and PhD under the excellent supervision of Prof. Keun Ho Ryu from the Department of Computer Science at Chungbuk National University, South Korea. I studied my bachelor in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia at the National University of Mongolia where my thesis topic was on demand forcasting with regression analysis.

My current research focus is on meta-learning, memory and attention systems, rapid and temporal adaptations and learning feedbacks in artificial neural networks.

As a graduate student, I had a chance to work for a couple of startups where we focused on personalized document processing pipeline and search engine at scale. I also used to participate in Kaggle competitions and held the competitions expert badge from the Kaggle community.

A few sport activities I attemp to do are weight training, volleyball and swimming. I also like to have beer while playing pool and discussing ideas and technology.

Highlights

  • Metalearned Neural Memory got accepted at NeurIPS 2019!
  • We successfully organized DLUB 2019 - a summer school on deep learning. The theme this year was NLP.
  • Selected for ICML travel award: I am very grateful to the International Machine Learning Society.
  • Our paper, Meta Networks (MetaNet) is accepted at ICML 2017!
  • Our paper on reasoning with memory augmented neural networks is accepted at ICLR 2017!
  • I am giving a talk at the MLFL on 2/14 [slides].
  • Our two long paper submissions (Neural Tree Indexers and Neural Semantic Encoders) are accepted at EACL 2017!
  • We opensourced the implementation of our Full tree matching NTI-SLSTM-LSTM model, which obtains 87.3% accuracy on Stanford NLI dataset.
  • Our paper on citation analysis with neural attention models (pdf) is accepted for EMNLP 2016 LOUHI workshop.
  • My dissertation is available: Domain Knowledge-rich Biomedical Information Extraction Methods based on Deep Neural Networks.
  • I got the chance to attend Deep Learning Summer School 2015 in Montreal. There I presented our poster: DeepText: End-to-end biomedical event extraction via deep learning and recursive projection model

Open source software

  • DeepText: An end-to-end biomedical event extraction system based on deep learning and recursive projection model, written in Scala and Lua (using Torch).
  • BANNER-CHEMDNER: A multi-domain named entity recognition system that can be used to identify chemical and drug mention, biomedical mention or disease mention from text, written in Java.

    Placed 6th (out of 23) in the CHEMDNER chemical document indexing subtask and 8th (out of 26) in the Chemical entity mention recognition subtask
